Next Congress

Boston Atlas

Unionist full issue 1833-09-05

Section: Item Display

Next Congress.—The patriotic State of North Carolina will present an almost undivided phalanx
at Washington next winter against Nullification. Carson is beaten, and there are
but two members chosen whose course will run side and side with McDuffie &
Co. More than two thirds of the Delegation are friendly to the re-charter of the
Bank. It gives us pleasure to learn that in the Fayetteville district,
represented in the last Congress by Mr. Bethune, a semi-nullifier, the new
member is both in favor of the Bank and Mr. Clay’s Land Bill. It is remarkable
that Mr. Bethune was beaten by precisely the same majority that he was elected
two years ago.—
Boston Atlas.

Section: Featured Content

Above: Sketch of Congressman Samuel Price Carson (1798-1838), slave-owner and duelist

Commentary

One of these defeated Congressman, Lauchlin Bethune, was a slave-owner; the other, Samuel Price Carson, was a slaveowner and had killed a man in a duel over a campaign insult.

Transcription
Next Congress.—The patriotic State of North Carolina will present an almost undivided phalanx
at Washington next winter against Nullification. Carson is beaten, and there are
but two members chosen whose course will run side and side with McDuffie &
Co. More than two thirds of the Delegation are friendly to the re-charter of the
Bank. It gives us pleasure to learn that in the Fayetteville district,
represented in the last Congress by Mr. Bethune, a semi-nullifier, the new
member is both in favor of the Bank and Mr. Clay’s Land Bill. It is remarkable
that Mr. Bethune was beaten by precisely the same majority that he was elected
two years ago.—
Boston Atlas.
Commentary
One of these defeated Congressman, Lauchlin Bethune, was a slave-owner; the other, Samuel Price Carson, was a slaveowner and had killed a man in a duel over a campaign insult.
Related People
Samuel Price Carson; George McDuffie; Henry Clay: Lauchlin Bethune.
